Ã— Junk in the trunk? St. Louis Zoo elephants on successful weight loss program
ST. LOUIS, Mo. â€” Junk in the trunk? The elephants at the St. Louis Zoo are undergoing a weight loss program. Ron Mott, a reporter from the Today Show, says that the Zoo is closely monitoring the pachydermâ€™s girth.
Nearly 75 percent of elephants are overweight according to a study of Zoo animals from 2011. Raja, the St. Louis Zooâ€™s famous 26-year-old elephant, is one of the overweight elephants. He weighs anywhere from 9,500 lbs to 10,500 lbs. The Zoo says that although he is a large elephant, he is in good condition.
Today reports that the St. Louis Zoo came up with a recipe to keep the pound off. Theyâ€™re using feeders that force the animals to work for food. Theyâ€™re also eating smaller, more frequent meals, and switching up the locations of some snacks.
The goal is to keep active. The elephants appear to enjoy exercise with the reward of a treat.
The changes put in place for the Zooâ€™s Asian elephants appear to be working. They have minimized weight-related problems like joint and foot issues.
The St. Louis Zoo posted a picture to Twitter of the news crew at the Zoo.

A long time ago, I heard a story about the origin of Obi Wan. A few Star Wars fans had noticed a similarity between the sound of his name and that of some of the other characters. 

A couple of examples are C3PO and R2D2. They're also call Artoo and Threepio for short. Now take Obiwan's name and run this idea in the other direction Obi Wan could also be OB1. It was theorized that this might indicate some kind of as-yet-unrevealed backstory that Obi Wan was a clone of some sort. 

So I ran with the idea. And it started to make it's own kind of sense the more I thought about it. It goes something like this. 

Once upon a time, a small group of Jedi got an idea. Let's take advantage of this new cloning technology and try and clone ourselves. Just as was done later with Jango Fett, the clones were to be based on a superior example. The Jedi selected a young Jedi Master named *Ben* Kenobi. 

The location for the cloning facility was an obscure planet just south of the Rishi Maze named Kamino. There, the Jedi requested the clones to be produced in batches of 100 clones each. Each clone would have it's own unique alphanumeric designation according to it's unit number within each batch. The very first clone to be produced in this fashion would therefore be known as Original Batch, number one. Or OB1, for short. 

Ben Kenobi gave his DNA sample to the Kaminoans and the process got underway. Unfortunately for the Jedi, there was a problem. It was the midichlorians. In a totally unforeseen turn of events, the midichlorians did not replicate along with the rest of the body's cell during the cloning process. There was only one single multiplication instead of the hundred that was expected. 

What's more, only one of the clones received the these midichlorians. The first clone, OB1. The rest of the clones came out of the process physically complete and perfect in every way except the one that mattered most. They had not one single midichlorian amongst the lot. Ninety-nine clones of Ben Kenobi, completely lacking in any Jedi powers whatsoever. It was a disaster and the whole project was immediately canceled..... never to be mentioned again. Even the location of Kamino itself was deleted from the Jedi library. The 99 powerless clones were quitely relocated. Each one to a separate planet, scattered across the far reaches of the Republic. 

There was one small success though. OB1. Based on an already powerful Jedi, but with twice the level of midichlorians. The young OB1 was renamed Obi Wan and entered into Jedi training at the earliest possible age. As young Obi Wan progressed through his training the Jedi council came to realize that he would soon be a very powerful Jedi. 

When OB1 became the Paduwan of Qui Gonn Jinn, Ben Kenobi retired to a far off world called Tatooine. This was done in order to avoid the rest of the Jedi from noticing that he had been cloned. 

Eventually OB1, now known as Obi Wan, came to fulfill his potential. He was in fact, a type of super Jedi. A few years passed and the time came when the Sith chose to reveal themselves.

Since the inception and uptake of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) in the 90s and early 00s, much neurolinguistic research has been undertaken to discover the neural correlates of speech production and perception [1] . A concurrent improvement to existing electroencephalography (EEG) technology has improved access and lowered cost, and neurolinguistic research has gradually shifted in its favour. However, for decoding inner and imagined speech, many EEG studies note the processing advantages that are gained from the signals offered by fMRI data (e.g. [2, 3, 4] ). As such, a nascent interest in combining the two modalities has emerged: for speech and language processing, bimodal fusion methods have more recently been applied to paradigms for auditory decoding from oddball paradigms [5, 6] , speech-gesture integration [7, 8] , and speech and language mapping [9, 10] .
Both recording modalities have their own benefits: EEG has fine-grained millisecond temporal accuracy of up to 16,000 Hz, but limited spatial resolution. In contrast, fMRI has high 1mm spatial precision, but weak temporal resolution. Combining these two modalities can compensate for their individual limitations, and has been shown to improve decoding performance over unimodal decoding [11] .
Whilst fMRI has been used extensively to investigate the neural correlates of speech (e.g. [12, 13, 14] ), it is only recently gaining traction for brain-computer interface (BCI)-motivated inner speech decoding. Using three subjects, Tang et al. [15] demonstrate how fMRI may successfully be used to reconstruct perceived continuous natural language based on its semantic representation; the decoder was used to subsequently identify, via pair-wise classification, which of five story transcripts the participant was imagining. Other support for fMRI-based language decoding comes from Correia et al.'s study in which spoken words were shown to be decodable across languages based on semantic representations [16] .
EEG is also an increasingly-popular BCI tool for inner speech decoding; recently, van den Berg et al. [17] report a 35% model accuracy with a 4-class inner speech decoding paradigm, while Kiroy et al. [18] report model accuracies from 33% to 40% with a 7-class inner speech task-notably both of these studies employed paradigms restricted to 'spatial direction' words. Decoding performances have also been shown to remain stable with commercial-grade dry electrode EEG devices which record the brain signal with lower fidelity and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR): Clayton et al.

The players Bristol Rovers fans want to sign for
The best of what Rovers fans had to say this seas
Peterbough United fans have been quick to suggest their club might be interested in Bristol City defender Mark Little.
The Robins announced their retained list yesterday evening, and in it revealed that would not be extending Littleâ€™s contract.
The right back will be leaving Ashton Gate after a difficult season but one that saw him being a fundamental part of the line-up that secured a run of six victories at the end of the season.
(Photo: Pete Norton/Getty Images)
Having been at League One Peterborough immediately prior to him signing for City the third tier club is no stranger to him.
He was at Wolves from 2005 until 2010 and proved his worth while out on loan at Northampton Town, Peterborough and Chesterfield.
It was then on May 24 in 2010 that Little signed for Peterborough in a three-year deal.
(Photo: Jan Kruger/Getty Images)
Now City have released the 28-year-old is seems the POSH faithful are keen to have him back.
If he is successful in signing for the club then he will no doubt be supported next season by City fans when he takes on arch rivals Bristol Rovers.
